discussion.content:
I went for Transitive but after some research am going for MITM.

A note from the internet states:

"A client-side attack uses an application on the client computer, such as a web browser.
A transitive access attack attempts to access a back-end server through another server.
A SQL injection attack is an example of a transitive access attack that can bypass many other security controls."

comments.content: Not sure bro. I mean the proxy has always been legitimately performing man in the middle and signing all certificates with his own internal certificate. My guts tell me this is MITM.

discussion.content: Would this not be transitive access? The internal host trusts the website because the proxy says its valid? I also see how it can be man in the middle but feel transitive access attack is more specific....

questions.question_text:
A network administrator is attempting to troubleshoot an issue regarding certificates on a secure website.
During the troubleshooting process, the network administrator notices that the web gateway proxy on the local network has signed all of the certificates on the local machine.
Which of the following describes the type of attack the proxy has been legitimately programmed to perform?

A company discovers an unauthorized device accessing network resources through one of many network drops in a common area used by visitors.
The company decides that it wants to quickly prevent unauthorized devices from accessing the network but policy prevents the company from making changes on every connecting client.
Which of the following should the company implement?

discussion.content:
"Prevents the company from making changes on 'every connecting client'"
I guess they're talking about the least intrusive choice that will affect the least amount of clients? Which is why its A?

choices.C: Install and configure NAC services to allow only authorized devices to connect to the network.
choices.D: Analyze normal behavior on the network and configure the IDS to alert on deviations from normal.
choices.A: Remove and replace the managed switch with an unmanaged one.
choices.B: Implement a separate logical network segment for management interfaces.

questions.question_text: An organization has recently recovered from an incident where a managed switch had been accessed and reconfigured without authorization by an insider. The incident response team is working on developing a lessons learned report with recommendations. Which of the following recommendations will BEST prevent the same attack from occurring in the future?

discussion.content: B is correct. Management interfaces should always be on a separate VLAN from production VLAN if possible.
This question was in the exam :)
None of the other answers make sense, but B. Transitive trust is a Microsoft AD thing. A quick Google couldn't find anything remotely showing B.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a control that allows a mobile application to access and manipulate information which should only be available by another application on the same mobile device (e.g. a music application posting the name of the current song playing on the device on a social media site)?

Using a heuristic system to detect an anomaly in a computer's baseline, a system administrator was able to detect an attack even though the company signature based IDS and antivirus did not detect it. Further analysis revealed that the attacker had downloaded an executable file onto the company PC from the USB port, and executed it to trigger a privilege escalation flaw. Which of the following attacks has MOST likely occurred?

comments.content: With the info provided, zero day has to be the MOST likely... think thatâ€™s the word we need to focus on here. We have to believe the IDS/AV is up to date. Using heuristic as an example pushes me to think they want you to understand you combat a zero day attack by using heuristic techniques.

discussion.content: is this really zero-day? or considered zero day since it is not detected by IDS and AV?
